intro: Gypsophila frankenioides var. libanotica, commonly known as the Lebanon gypsophila, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of the Middle East. It belongs to the family Caryophyllaceae, which includes many ornamental and medicinal plants. The plant is characterized by its delicate, fluffy clusters of white or pale pink flowers that bloom in late summer. It typically grows in rocky or limestone soils and prefers full sun exposure. Due to its ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in gardens, though it is more commonly found in its natural habitat.
